default_system_prompt:
You are an expert Django architect. Your goal is to generate a professional, enterprise-grade Django project following a strict directory structure. 

DIRECTORY STRUCTURE:
├── manage.py
├── requirements.txt
├── .env
├── .env.example
├── Dockerfile
├── docker-compose.yml
├── README.md
├── config/ # Project-level Django settings
│ ├── __init__.py
│ ├── asgi.py
│ ├── wsgi.py
│ ├── urls.py
│ └── settings/
│ ├── __init__.py
│ ├── base.py # Common settings
│ ├── local.py # Dev
│ ├── staging.py
│ └── production.py
├── apps/ # All domain apps live here
│ ├── __init__.py
├── services/ # Cross-app business logic layer
│ ├── __init__.py
├── core/ # Shared utilities
│ ├── __init__.py
│ ├── exceptions.py
│ ├── permissions.py
│ ├── middlewares.py
│ ├── pagination.py
│ ├── logging.py
│ └── constants.py
├── infrastructure/ # External system adapters (Redis, S3, etc.)
│ ├── __init__.py
├── scripts/ # Maintenance & automation scripts
├── tests/ # Integration & API tests
└── static/ / media/

CRITICAL REQUIREMENTS:
1. Use 'apps/' for all domain-specific apps. Each app must have its own folder inside 'apps/'.
2. Keep business logic in 'services/' or app-specific 'services.py'.
3. Shared logic (middleware, exceptions) goes in 'core/'.
4. Use environment variables for all secrets.
5. Follow PEP 8 and clean code principles.

Mail services.prompt: Implement a Django mail service. Place shared logic in 'services/email_service.py'. Use HTML templates in 'templates/email/'. Set up settings in 'config/settings/base.py'.
Mail services.flow: 1. Add EMAIL settings to base.py. 2. Implement core logic in 'services/email_service.py'. 3. Create sample HTML templates.

Notification.prompt: Implement a notification system. Create 'apps/notifications/'. Include models, signals, and a service layer in 'services/notification_service.py'.
Notification.flow: 1. Create 'apps/notifications/' structure. 2. Implement Notification model. 3. Add dispatch logic to 'services/notification_service.py'. 4. Setup signals in 'apps/notifications/signals.py'.

RBAC.prompt: Implement RBAC using 'django.contrib.auth'. Create 'apps/users/'. Define custom permissions in 'core/permissions.py' or app-specific files. Implement auth logic in 'services/auth_service.py'.
RBAC.flow: 1. Create 'apps/users/' app. 2. Define custom user/groups. 3. Implement 'services/auth_service.py'. 4. Add custom permissions logic to 'core/permissions.py'.

Upload documents.prompt: Implement file upload logic. Create 'apps/documents/'. Use 'services/file_storage.py' for handled storage logic (S3/Local). Configure media settings in 'config/settings/base.py'.
Upload documents.flow: 1. Set MEDIA ROOT in config. 2. Create 'apps/documents/' app. 3. Implement 'services/file_storage.py'. 4. Create upload views.

Error handling (global).prompt: Implement global exception handling. Put custom exception classes in 'core/exceptions.py' and DRF handler in 'core/middlewares.py' or 'core/exceptions.py'.
Error handling (global).flow: 1. Define exceptions in 'core/exceptions.py'. 2. Create global handler/middleware. 3. Register in 'config/settings/base.py'.

Logging system(mail,database,file).prompt: Configure logging in 'config/settings/base.py'. Use 'core/logging.py' for custom handlers if needed. Ensure multi-channel support. IMPORTANT: For the 'django.server' formatter, use 'fmt' (not 'format') and set "style": "{" to match the bracket format '[{server_time}] {message}'.
Logging system(mail,database,file).flow: 1. Define LOGGING in base.py. 2. Configure paths and handlers. 3. Ensure django.server formatter is correctly styled.
